intro: Salvia reducta, commonly known as narrowleaf sage, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring narrow, lance-shaped leaves with a grayish-green hue. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically purple or violet, arranged in dense clusters at the ends of the stems. Salvia reducta thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a hardy addition to rock gardens and xeriscapes.
